stimulusHtml: A block is attached to one end of a horizontal spring. The block is displaced by a distance Δx from equilibrium, and when the block is released, it oscillates in simple harmonic motion with period T. If the block is displaced by a distance 2Δx, it will also oscillate in simple harmonic motion with period T. Why does the period not increase when the initial displacement increases?
choicesHtml: Because the equilibrium position will change when the initial displacement changes such that the block oscillates with the same amplitude and the same average speed.
Because the spring constant of the spring decreases with increasing displacement, which makes the block move with greater average speed when it is displaced more.
Because the spring exerts the same force on the block at the maximum displacement of the block, in both scenarios.
Because even though the block travels a larger distance during one oscillation when the initial displacement is greater, the average speed also increases by the same factor.
